metadata.description: Cooks create the delicious dishes we have come to expect at restaurants. They aren’t afraid of fast-paced work—taking on the challenge of turning raw ingredients into wonderful creations.

markdown:
Skip to main content

![chef in kitchen](/sites/default/files/2023-01/cook-class-02.jpg)

As a Cook, you’re an artisan of food, taking dishes from concept to preparation and delivery. You’re an attentive individual, looking out for high standards in every meal you create, while showing your signature style. 

You’ll be able to multi-task, shining when faced with the adrenaline rush of a tight deadline. This may be as part of a team in a small kitchen or as the lead at a large station.

#### What You'll Learn

  * How to order, organize and store food safely 
  * How to prepare and cook with a wide variety of ingredients 
  * How to experiment with different flavours and cuisines
  * How to create dishes and plan menus
  * How to prepare food for all sorts of customers, occasions and events



#### Key Job Skills

  * Active listening and monitoring
  * Coordination and time management
  * Menu planning, ordering and inventory
  * Cost management and front-of-house procedures
  * Preparing stocks, soups, sauces, meats, baked goods, desserts and beverages



#### Technical Training

To get certified, you will need to sign up for technical training at an approved training provider in addition to on-the-job training. 

Visit [Trades Training BC](https://www.tradestrainingbc.ca/) and [EducationPlannerBC](https://educationplannerbc.ca/search) for a comprehensive list of what programs are available in your trade at public and non-public schools. 

For a list of all approved non-public training providers, [visit this page](/all-approved-training-providers-list).

Technical Training 6 weeks over 2 years 

Work-Based Training

3000 HOURS

General Skills

[Creative](/find-your-trade?f%5B0%5D=skills_taxonomy_term_name%3ACreative) [Expressive](/find-your-trade?f%5B0%5D=skills_taxonomy_term_name%3AExpressive) [Precise](/find-your-trade?f%5B0%5D=skills_taxonomy_term_name%3APrecise) [Visual](/find-your-trade?f%5B0%5D=skills_taxonomy_term_name%3AVisual)

_For more information regarding the other levels in this progressive trade, please refer to the following program pages:_

  * [_Professional Cook 1_](/professional-cook-1)

  * [Professional Cook 2](/professional-cook-2)




**Program Updates:**

  * **March 2022:** [ _Program Update_](/media/677/download) (Harmonization implementation postponed)

  * **July 2021:** [_Program Update_](/media/678/download) (Harmonization implementation postponed)

  * **July 2020:** [_Program Update_](/media/688/download) (Assessment Guidelines added to the Program Outline)

  * **January 1, 2020:** [_Program Update_](/media/679/download) (Practical Assessment Document Update)

  * [_OPSN Archives_](/program-standards-updates)




**Note: A VALID**[** _FOODSAFE_**](http://www.foodsafe.ca/courses/level-1.html)**Level 1 Certification or**[** _equivalent_**](http://www.bccdc.ca/resource-gallery/Documents/Guidelines%20and%20Forms/Guidelines%20and%20Manuals/EH/FPS/Food/Food_Handlers_Training_Courses_Equivalent_to_BC_FOODSAFE_Level_1.pdf)**is a pre-requisite to challenge this certification.**

Professional Cook 3 Indigenous Content (PC3IC)

The Professional Cook 3 Indigenous Content (PC3IC) program outline was developed to introduce Indigenous culture through food gathering and preparation, and to bring back traditional knowledge. This program was designed so that apprentices can complete the level of apprenticeship training while learning the Indigenous culture from their specific area.

It is important to note that with respect to cultural and regional differences, Indigenous content may be adapted, but only with the recipes or regional ingredients. The context of the Indigenous content in the program outline must be followed as set forth.

[**Download Program Outline**](/media/1773/download)

Practical Assessment Information

  * As of **January 1, 2020** , all training providers are expected to use updated Practical Assessment documents that are dated **January 2020; all previous documents are no longer relevant.**

  * Details of the assessment criteria are contained within the [_Cook Assessment General Information package_](/media/670/download). Candidates can view the practical assessment preparation package for [_Menu A_](/media/691/download), [_Menu B_](/media/692/download) _,_ and [_Menu C_](/media/1837/download).

  * Please note that there is a fee attached to the practical assessment for challengers and re-assessment for apprentices which is set by the training provider conducting the assessment and may range between $350-$500. A [ _list of assessment venues_](/media/2442/download) is sent to you with your approval to challenge.




## 

Program Information and Resources

#### [Program Profile Occupational Description Cooks perform all phases of kitchen activities including the preparation and presentation of vegetables, soups, sauces, meat, cold kitchen items, desserts, baking and pastry. They have extensive knowledge of safety, sanitation and food storage, they handle basic menu planning and costing, and they help handle customer relations.  A Professional Cook 3 will have met all of the requirements of the national Red Seal standard for Cook. They usually work under limited supervision and will be competent at the major techniques and principles used in cooking, baking, and other aspects of food preparation. In addition to a sound set of cooking skills, a professional cook at this level should be able to plan and cost menus and recipes, and have an understanding of the communication skills that will be necessary to begin to take a leadership role in the kitchen. View Program Profile](/media/689/download)

#### [Program Outline Guidelines for delivery of technical training at SkilledTradesBC Recognized Training Providers View PDF](/media/687/download) #### [Record Book An easy-to-use tool to help you identify your trades training needs, track your progress, and move towards certification.  View PDF](/media/2519/download)

Exam Information and Resources

Interprovincial Red Seal Exam

  * **June 2022:**[Program Update](/media/690/download) (2019 Red Seal Occupational Standard (RSOS))
  * A Comparative Analysis detailing changes between the 2011 National Occupational Analysis (NOA), the 2015 NOA, and the 2019 RSOS can be found [here](/media/694/download).

## 

Challenge the Trade

If you have significant work experience in a trade but have never been certified in Canada, you may apply to challenge the certification. Learn more about [How to Challenge a Skilled Trade](/challenge-skilled-trade).

OR

If you sponsor apprentices but have never been certified in Canada, you may request to supervise and sign-off apprentices when they are ready to be certified. Please [contact customer service](/contact-us) for more information.

#### [Instructions How to Apply View](https://skilledtradesbc.ca/instructions-challenge-certification) #### [Online Application Sign up for the Portal to start your online application View PDF](https://portal.skilledtradesbc.ca/Account/Login/Register?registrationType=certified) #### [Employer Declaration Document of relevant work experience View PDF](/media/781/download) #### [Statutory Declaration Attestation for self-employment/work experience when employer cannot be contacted View PDF](/media/782/download)
